question_title: what is a conjugated bridge? [SEP] question_content: part of the body [SEP] best_answer: A hfr cell (also called hfr strain) is a bacterium with a conjugative plasmid (often F) integrated into its genomic DNA. Hfr is the abbreviation for high frequency recombination, which was first characterized by Luca Cavalli-Sforza. Unlike a normal F+ cell, hfr strains will, upon conjugation with a F- cell, attempt to transfer their entire DNA through the mating bridges (called pili) to the F- cell. This occurs because the F factor has integrated itself via an insertion point in the bacterial chromosome. Due to the F factor's inherent nature to transfer itself over the pilus during bacteria conjugation, the rest of the bacterial genome is dragged along with it, thus making such cells very useful and interesting in terms of studying gene linkage and recombination.

A structure as fragile as a mating bridge will, however, likely break, and so the transfer is rarely complete. Thus, the F- cell uses only part of the genomic DNA of the Hfr cell for recombination. Though there is some debate on the issue, the pili themselves do not seem to be the structures through which the actual exchange of DNA takes place; rather, some proteins seem to open a channel between the bacteria.

It should also be noted that the bacterial genome's rate of transfer through the pilus is constant; this allows molecular biologists and geneticists to use Hfr strain of bacteria (often E. Coli) to study genetic linkage and map the chromosome. The procedure commonly used for this is called interrupted mating.

question_title: If it takes 4 workers 3 days to frame 2 houses, how many days will it take 3 workers to frame 5 houses? [SEP] question_content: Asssuming that they work the same rate?

Someone answer me that ASAP!

I think it might be 2 [SEP] best_answer: Rate = 2 houses / (4 workers * 3 days)
Rate = 1/6 house per worker per day.

3 workers * n days * 1/6 house/worker = 5 houses
n = 5 * 6 / 3
n = 30 / 3
n = 10 days

question_title: Math equation!!!? [SEP] question_content: Solve this....

g over 5-7 = -27......how do u do this??? [SEP] best_answer: g/(5 - 7) = -27 
The approach is to move the numbers to one side of the equation and the g's to the other [although you have only one 'g']

You can add/subtract/multiply/divide the same thing from both sides of an equation.

So, lets multiply both sides by (5 - 7):
(g/(5 - 7) )* (5 - 7) = -27 * (5 - 7)
then,
g = -27 * (-2)
g = +54 [since multiplying two minuses makes a plus]

Hope this helps!

question_title: if an anchor is dropped from a boat into a lake, will the water level of the lake rise or fall? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Say the anchor weighs 15 pounds in air and displaces 2 pounds of water.
Before the drop, the boat displaces its weight plus the 15 lb weight in air of the anchor. This is the maximum displacement situation, so the water is at maximum height.
After the drop, if the anchor hits bottom, the boat displaces its weight only and the anchor displaces 2 lb of water, the minimum displacement situation, so the water is at minimum height.
After the drop, if the anchor doesn't reach the bottom, the boat displaces its weight plus the 13 lb weight in water of the anchor. The anchor displaces 2 lb water. The total displacement is the same as the maximum displacement situation, so the water is at maximum height.

question_title: can we trap light after the source of which is turned off so that we can open the trap and see the light in it [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Say you shine a flashlight into a mirror. Then put a mirror behind the flashlight and remove the flashlight. Given that the 2 mirrors are exactly parallel, will the light just bounce back and forth forever? No - the light travels in waves and each time it reflects back, some of the light is not hitting the mirror exactly at 90 degrees and is reflected off on an angle. The light will reflect away and eventually dissipate completely. \nIf you try to trap light in a box, as it bounces off the walls inside, it will dissipate into energy (heat). The temperature of the inside of the box will raise - but just infintestimly so.\nRemember all of this will take place at the speed of light.

question_title: What causes the movement of wind? [SEP] question_content: And what causes it to come to an end? [SEP] best_answer: Wind is the roughly horizontal movement of air (as opposed to an air current) caused by uneven heating of the Earth's surface. It occurs at all scales, from local breezes generated by heating of land surfaces and lasting tens of minutes to global winds resulting from solar heating of the Earth. The two major influences on the atmospheric circulation are the differential heating between the equator and the poles, and the rotation of the planet (Coriolis effect).

Given a difference in barometric pressure between two air masses, a wind will arise between the two which tends to flow from the area of high pressure to the area of low pressure until the two air masses are at the same pressure, although these flows will be modified by the Coriolis effect in the extratropics.

Winds can be classified either by their scale, the kinds of forces which cause them (according to the atmospheric equations of motion), or the geographic regions in which they exist. There are global winds, such as the wind belts which exist between the atmospheric circulation cells. There are upper-level winds, such as the jet streams. There are synoptic-scale winds that result from pressure differences in surface air masses in the middle latitudes, and there are winds that come about as a consequence of geographic features such as the sea breeze. Mesoscale winds are those which act on a local scale, such as gust fronts. At the smallest scale are the microscale winds which blow on a scale of only tens to hundreds of metres and are essentially unpredictable, such as dust devils and microbursts.

question_title: Can you solve this? [SEP] question_content: A bullet train take some hours to cover a distance of 2100 km. at some speed.If the speed is increased 70 km/hr,then it takes 5hrs. less to cover the same distance.Find the speed of the Train.
If you'll get the answer then also give the verification.

PLZ give me the answer before Tuesday.Its for my Homework. [SEP] best_answer: In the first instance, the train is traveling 140 km/hr for 15 hours, 140x15=2100.

In the second instance, the train is traveling 210 km/hr for 10 hours, 210x10=2100.

sh=2100
(s+70)(h-5)=2100
sh+70h-5s-350=2100
from equation 1, sh=2100, therefore
2100+70h-5s-350=2100
70h-5s-350=0
14h-s=70
14h-70=s
by substitution in equation 1,
(14h-70)h=2100
14hh-70h-2100=0
hh-5h-150=0
(h-15)(h+10)=0
h=15 or -10
h cannot be negative, therefore h=15
substituting h in equation 1
15s=2100
s=140

question_title: How does battery-charging without physical contact work? [SEP] question_content: I thought that you need a physical contact between the charger and the battery so the electricity actually arrives inside the battery.
Now my new electrical toothbrush seems to work differently. It has a battery, the manual confirms. It also has a charger. But all I need to do is to put the toothbrush on the charger.

How does that work? Both parts are plastic covered. [SEP] best_answer: Its using induction charge principle. Essentially the primary coil side of the transformer is built into the base and the secondary coil is built into the toothbrush. 

The primary winding of the inductive charger transmits charging power to the secondary winding, inside the target device, without making direct electrical or mechanical contact with it. In the target device, power is received with a coil and then rectified by a diode. This DC voltage is used in charging the battery of the device.

question_title: Power/force? [SEP] question_content: The 4.00-kg block is moving to the right on a horizontal frictionless surface at 3.00 m/s when force F delivers an instantaneous power of 25.0 W to the block. θ = 50.0°. What is the magnitude of the force, F?
-if you could show some steps of how to get the answer, that would be great :) [SEP] best_answer: P=W/t
P=Fdcosθ/t         (as we know W=Fdcosθ})
P=Fvcosθ           (as we know v(avg.)=d/t)
therefore
25=F3cos50
F=12.96 N   (ans)

question_title: what is big bang? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: In physical cosmology, the Big Bang is the scientific theory that the universe emerged from an enormously dense and hot state about 13.7 billion years ago. The Big Bang theory is based on the observed Hubble's law redshift of distant galaxies that when taken together with the cosmological principle indicate that space is expanding according to the Friedmann-Lemaître model of general relativity. Extrapolated into the past, these observations show that the universe has expanded from a state in which all the matter and energy in the universe was at an immense temperature and density. Physicists do not widely agree on what happened before this, although general relativity predicts a gravitational singularity (for reporting on some of the more notable speculation on this issue, see cosmogony).

The term Big Bang is used both in a narrow sense to refer to a point in time when the observed expansion of the universe (Hubble's law) began — calculated to be 13.7 billion (1.37 × 1010) years ago (±2%) — and in a more general sense to refer to the prevailing cosmological paradigm explaining the origin and expansion of the universe, as well as the composition of primordial matter through nucleosynthesis as predicted by the Alpher-Bethe-Gamow theory [1].

One consequence of the Big Bang is that the conditions of today's universe are different from the conditions in the past or in the future (natural evolution of universe constantly takes place). From this model, George Gamow in 1948 was able to predict, at least qualitatively, the existence of cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) [2]. The CMB was discovered in the 1960s and further validated the Big Bang theory over its chief rival, the steady state theory.

question_title: What happens to the body when somebody has taken an lethal overdose? [SEP] question_content: Could it be the brain shuts down first or the other organs start to fail continusoly?  If a postmorten came out with the lungs undefected, how come they didnt get affected? [SEP] best_answer: It sounds like you have a particular scenario in mind, so here goes...

People who use street drugs develop a tolerance to them, so they need bigger and bigger doses to "get high." Sometimes they increase the dose too much and overdose. Another problem is purity. Average street drugs are only about 50% the actual drug, and 50% filler to increase the dealer's profit margin(although heroin has gotten much more pure recently...). When an addict gets drugs from a different supplier, he might get a different concentration than what he's used to and unintentionally overdose.

Cocaine and amphetamines ("meth") are stimulants. An OD on them can cause a heart attack, where the heart stops beating, blood flow to the brain stops, and the person dies. It would not cause any obvious lung damage.

Most other drugs of abuse--opiates (heroin, oxycodone, vicodin, demerol etc.), alcohol, GHB, benzodiazepines (xanax, valium, clonapin) slow down the rate and/or depth of your breathing so you go to sleep and stop breathing. This causes lack of oxygen in the blood, and this causes brain damage leading to death.

Neither of these paths will cause any visible damage to the lungs.  Most of the damage is at the cellular level, so to the naked eye, the organs look normal.

question_title: Why are meteorologists so inaccurate? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Try this - predict, to the second, how long it will take to boil 1 liter of water. 

Then, test it. You will quickly see that there are MANY factors involved (is the pan a good conductor of heat? Electric or gas stove? Is the water 100% pure? What is the barometric pressure? What setting are you using to heat the cooktop?) and that it is impossible to predict with 100% certainty what will or won't happen. 

That is essentially what meteorologists do - They try to predict the occurrence of something we know is possible by knowing very limited information.

question_title: Base triplet on T-RNA recognizing complementary base triplet on M-RNA? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: t-RNA or transfer RNA consists of short RNA coupled to specific amino acids.  mRNA is translated into protein in ribozomes, via pairing with tRNA.  The pairing takes the form of a three letter code called a codon.  The pairing bases occur on the tRNA in the stem-loop structure.  The pairing is complementary, A with U, C with G.  However, the third position of the anti-codon on the tRNA is called the wobble position because an unusual nucleotide, inosine, can be found in some tRNAs.  This nucleotide can bind to A, U, or C. This leads to a single tRNA with a single amino acid being able to recognize and bind different codons.  Evolutionarily, it means that mutations in the coding sequence of DNA will not necessarily cause a change in the protein, depending on if the mutation is a point mutation of a wobble position.

question_title: how do classification systems help us to think about and study diversity on earth? [SEP] question_content: lots of detail please [SEP] best_answer: Taxonomic classification systems are useful for a couple of significant reasons.  First and foremost, it creates a name for each living organism that ALL scientists can agree upon.  Therefore, biologists on opposite sides of the world can be confident that they are discussing the same organism when looking at the taxonomic label of that organism.  Secondly, the design of the system is useful for showing evolutionary relationships among organisms.  Generically, the breakdown is kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus and species.  There are five kingdoms (six in some systems) and millions upon millions of species.  For any two organisms, they are more closely related evolutionarily if they share a classification more toward the species.  For example, two organisms that share a genus are more closely related than two other organisms that only share a family.  You should know that there modifications of the above system so that you get things like subphyla, superfamilies, etc.  The genus and species names are GENeral and SPECIfic for a particular organism and are always written in italics, with the genus name being capitalized and the species name beginning with a lower-case letter.  The millions of species described by the system is a testimony to the great biodiversity of life on this planet.

question_title: Does anyone have tips on how to sleep with PVCs or PACs? [SEP] question_content: Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are considered harmless by the 3 doctors and 2 cardiologists I've seen, but what a pain in the ass!  Those of you who are as unfortunate as me to actually feel every single one of them, how do you cope?  I can't sleep, and then being tired makes them worse.  I take atenolol, but it doesn't seem to do much.  Does anyone have any favorite medicine to control them or sleep through them? [SEP] best_answer: Those doctors aren't very helpful sometimes, are they?  (  :

You're certainly not alone.  If it's serious enough that you can't sleep, then that in itself can be a real problem.  There are medications that MIGHT help, such as beta blockers (like propranolol and metoprolol), but these all have a bunch of other effects which it would be better to avoid if you can.

So you might want to try some lifestyle changes.  Chocolate, caffeine, alcohol, and exercise can all be triggers that increase the frequency of your arrythmias.  Unfortunately, so can stress - so worrying about whether you can get to sleep will unfortunately only make it harder to get to sleep!

Deep breathing will help you relax, and some people report that magnesium, calcium, and fish oil supplements can help too.

It's worth a try, anyway.  If none of those work, you might at least get some consolation from others with similar problems.  The first link below is to a forum that seems to have a number of people with PVCs and PACs.  Hope that helps!

question_title: I have no idea where to start on this question can anyone help???!? [SEP] question_content: Determine the value and sign of Delta H for the following reaction: 
                            2F-F  +  O=O --> 2F-O-F [SEP] best_answer: The reaction

F2 + O2 ===> 2F2O

dH = 2 dH F2O - (dH F2 + dH O2) wher d is the delta symbol and using the heats of formation

Since F2 and O2 are in the elemental state, the heat of formation is 0 (by definition)

dH = 2 x 24.5 = 49 kJ/mol

Delta H for the above is 49 kJ/mol

I got the heat of formation for F2O (difluorine monoxide) from Wikipedia.

question_title: Why would sound waves travel faster in liquids or solids than in air? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Molecules are closer together in liquids and solids than in gas. Soundwaves are motions of molecules that basically push off each other. In a dense liquid one molecule only has to move a tiny distance before it hits another molecule and so forth, whereas in a gas it takes a while before one molecule encounters another one along its path.

question_title: A question about the eyes? What are each of these two\nregions called and what is the importance of each in vision? [SEP] best_answer: There are two types of cells. Rod & cone cells. Rod cells are responsible for black & white vision, cone cells for color vision. at the yellow spot, there are only cone cells, at the other areas of the retina, there are rod cells. At the blind spot, there is neither.

question_title: What is a 3 digit number divisable by 7 but not 2-The sum of my digits is 4? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Because your result is odd (not divisible by 2), the last digit can't be 0 or 2, so it must be 1 or 3...

If the last digit is 3, the other digits must add to 1, so you have only one choice:
103

If the last digit is 1, the other digits must add to 3, so your choices are:
121
211
301

Now test each one to see if it is divisible by 7:
103 / 7 = 14.714285...
121 / 7 = 17.285714...
211 / 7 = 30.142857...
301 / 7 = 43

So the only number that fits your criteria is:
301

301 is 3 digits
301 is divisible by 7 (7 x 43)
301 is *not* divisible by 2
The sum of my digits (3 + 0 + 1) is 4.

question_title: what  is the difference between energy and force? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Although the words are used in many ways, science has specific definitions
for each.

Force is a push or a pull.  Force is between objects, one object pushing or
pulling on another.

Energy is more difficult to define, because energy is "abstract".  Energy is
a quantity that gives an object the ability to affect other objects.  There
are different kinds of energy.  Kinetic energy is the energy of motion,
stored within a moving object.  Potential energy is stored in the force
between objects, perhaps in the stretch of a spring.  Thermal energy can be
stored in the temperature of an object.  Energy passes from place to place,
object to object, but never disappears.  The total energy of the universe
remains constant.

Fuel is a material that has energy stored in its chemical structure.  When
fuel is processes (burned, for example), the chemical energy is released.
This released energy can become heat and cause the temperature of something
to rise.  The released energy can become the kinetic energy of a car.  It
can become the energy carried by sound to your ears.

question_title: The movement of sediment by the forces of nature is called? [SEP] question_content: These are the possible 4 answers:

A. weathering B. depostion C. erosion D. abrasion [SEP] best_answer: You need to think about this in terms of the question, that is what one of these processes involves movement of sediment.

Weathering does involve movement of sediment, since weathering includes lots of processes that break down rocks into smaller particles or even dissolve rocks. Dissolution of limestone by carbonic acid in water is weathering that 'moves' rock. Freeze-thaw weathering of sandstone breaks the sandstone into smaller particles that are carried away by water, gravity, and wind. 

Deposition is the end result of the process of moving sediment, and may be the only one that does not answer your question, but because it is part of the process of 'moving' sediment it probably counts. 

Erosion definitely moves sediment. Soil, sand, and rock are eroded by moving water and transported to new locations. 

Abrasion results in 'moving' sediment. Glaciers abrade underlying rock and grind it into small particles. Wind blows sand grains against rock and abrades it and reduces it to smaller particles. 

I think the only correct answer here is "all of the above.”

question_title: What's the carrying capacity of lynx rufus (bobcat)? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The carrying capacity is generally very hard to determine. With bobcats it may be near impossible as they do not cram in as many individuals as the land will hold, as a moose or deer will, so carrying capacity is different for them. The carrying capacity will also vary depending on the different habitat, it is generally determined for a type of ecosystem or a particular area. Bobcats set up territories, so the territory range within an acceptable habitat will determine how many bobcats there are. I doubt their population numbers ever even come close to the actual carrying capacity for them. With that said, from what i could find, it looks like there are around 7 bobcats/100km2. question_title: determining stoichiometry of Ni and en or EDA by Job's method? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Hello,

The idea behind Job's method is to prepare a series of reaction mixtures (for example solutions) in which the total number of moles of the reactants is fixed but with different ratio. One then plots the number of moles of product vs the ratio. The maximum of the curve will occur at the correct stoichiometric ratio.

In your case, one could prepare solutions containing a total number of moles (i.e. moles of Ni + moles EDA) equal to 1 with the following composition:

moles Ni     moles EDA Ratio Ni/EDA
0.9                0.1           9        
0.8                0.2           4
0.6                0.4          1.5
0.4                0.6          0.666
0.2                0.8          0.25
0.0                1.0          0.0

One then needs to measure the amount of Ni-EDA complex and plot that amount agains the ratio. The maximum will tell you which is the right stoichiometric ratio. Hope this helps. See the web site below for a more complete explanation.

One then measures the

question_title: chemicals used in gun blue? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Here is a "recipe" for gun bluing

Blue-Black Finish on Steel
 
a. Place object in molten sodium nitrate (700-800 degrees F) for 2-3 minutes. Remove and allow to cool somewhat; wash in hot water; dry and oil with mineral or linseed oil. 

b. Place in following solution for 15 minutes:
Copper sulphate 1/2 oz.
Iron Chloride 1 lb.
Hydrochloric acid 4 oz.
Nitric acid 1/2 oz.
Water 1 gallon
Then allow to dry for several hours; place in above solution again for 15 minutes; remove and dry for 10 hours. Place in boiling water for 1/2 hour; dry and scratch brush very lightly. Oil with mineral or linseed oil and wipe dry.

question_title: what is diffusion? give 2 examples of this occuring around your house.? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Diffusion is the flow of particles down the concentration gradient. Meaning that particles are flowing from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration. Two examples are this occuring around your house are
1. when you take a bubble bath. Even if you were to pour the bubbles in after the water stopped runnning the bubble mixture would still spread evenly throughout the water by simple diffusion.
2. when you light a scented cande. The scent travels throughout the whole house because it travels from an area of high concentration (right above the candle) to the rest of the areas around the house that have low concentrations of the scent.
Good? next time do your homework yourself :)

question_title: Should I address my grievance to the management, or sell these inferior goods on the secondary market? [SEP] question_content: Last month I ordered 41 gross of strut bearings for my temporal distorter matrix, since each use of the matrix tends to sublimate the 212 requisite bearings into a silvery Jackson-Pollock-esque mess on the ceiling of my garage. I was assured these bearings were mookie-proof.

However, upon closer examination, the mookination had transpired and was clearly underway. Now, I'm sure you're fully aware of the dire consequences that come when mookine interrupts a temporal rift - we all hang our heads sadly in rememberance of Andrew "Unsafe at any speed" Clayton of Westshireship, who, in 1996, had installed only 4 mookinated bearings in his primitive array of 143, disappeared for two weeks, and came back an inverted penguin.

So I ask you, should I sell these decidedly non-mookie-proof bearings on the secondary market, or complain to the management? [SEP] best_answer: Sell them on the secondary market. Complaining to management will get you nowhere.

question_title: What creates dark energy? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: By the law of conservation of energy, you cannot create or destroy energy, only change it from one form into another.

At the moment, dark energy and dark matter are theories which scientists have come up with to explain the "missing matter" in the universe.

question_title: why is the ocean water salty? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The basic answer to that is:
As water falls on land and runs into the oceans it picks up minerals.
When it gets to the ocean the minerals get mixed into the ocean water.
Sunlight causes the water to evaporate but leaves the minerals behind.
The water then falls on land again repeating the process.
Eventually the salt content in the oceans built up to where it is today. And continues to build up.

question_title: problem...? [SEP] question_content: Show each step involved in solving the following equation. Tell if any of them are extraneous:
sqrt(3x + 4) + x = 8

dumb question, but what does extraneous mean? [SEP] best_answer: sqrt(3x + 4) + x = 8
sqrt(3x + 4) = 8 - x
3x + 4 = 64 - 16x + x^2
0 = x^2 - 19x + 60
(x - 15)(x - 4) = 0
x = 4 or 15

Substitute x=4 into the original equation and it works.
Substitute x=15 into the original equation and it doesn't. It is extraneous.

question_title: Calculus II question please help? [SEP] question_content: This question was on my test and the answer was 3,272,500.
A tank is in the shape of a right circular cone of altitude 25 feet and base radius 20 feet with its vertex at the ground. (Think of an ice cream cone with its point facing down.) The tank is externally braced to prevent its falling over. If the tank is full of a fluid which weighs 50 pounds per cubic foot, find the work done, in foot pounds, correct to the nearest hundred footpounds, in pumping all of the fluid out of the top of the tank.

I received an answer that works but I don't know how they got 20000.  
Below is the answer that was posted
First, you need the volume. The formula yields: V = pi rh/3 = 20000pi/3 cubic feet. Since it weighs 50 pounds per cubic foot, the ratio 50 lbs/ft.^3 = 1. So multiplying this to our volume equation, V = 20000pi/3 ft.^3 = 20000pi/3 ft.^3 * 50lbs/ft.^3 = 100000pi/3 lbs. The work function is (25-x)100000pi/3 = W(x). Integrate this result from x=0 to x=25 [SEP] best_answer: why would you want to ask a math question, i thought school was over with

question_title: Challenge: On a map with ratio of 4:10000, a road is 12cm long. a) How long is the road on the ground.? [SEP] question_content: b) What is the area on the map if the actual area is 3.2 km^2? [SEP] best_answer: Part (a)
4:10000 scale means 4 cm distance on map represents 10000 cm or 100 m. Hence a 12 cm road is actually (12*100/4) = 300 m = 0.3 km long.

Part (b)
Length scale 4:10000 means area scale is (4*4):(10000*10000) i.e. 16:10^8. This means 10^8 cm^2 area will be represented by 16 cm^2 area on the map. Hence 3.2 km^2 = 3.2*10^10 cm^2 actual area is represented by (16*3.2*10^10/10^8) = 5120 cm^2 area on the map.

question_title: Did matter travel faster than light during big bang? [SEP] question_content: Also, what is the rate of expansion of the universe? and how do we know that it's accelerating and if so, will it (the rate of expansion) reach the speed of light? Can anyone explain in hopefully layman terms? [SEP] best_answer: this is somewhat similar to a question I answered realative to time travel. The short answer is no, there was never a time, nor will there ever be a time when matter (massive fermions) travel faster than light (massless bosons). This is because massive objects need energy to accelerate and regaurdless of how much energy was released in the big bang, it could not have been infinite, and that is what is required to move a massive particle faster than light. Light speed is not a derived measurement, it is a fundemental constant that is the same in all reference frames. Here's the cool exception though.....and this is how a theoretical warp drive would work..... the actual expansion of space itself might have been faster than light. There has never been a limit imposed on the speed at which space expands although because gravity is a result of the deformation of space and gravitons are the theoretical force carrier, it has been assumed that the expansion of space would occur only as fast as gravitons can travel....which is most likely light speed. One of the many postulates asserted by string theory is that gravitons may not be bound to our spatial demensions, that they might radiate through extra demensions (which would account for gravity's lack of strenght compared to the other forces). If this is the case that the gravitons travel through other demensions it is quite possible that within a given reference time, a graviton could pop into a superior demension and back into our at some other point and essentially beat light to some defined location.\n\nI know thats a little confusing.....but its fun to think about.

question_title: Inverse Functions? [SEP] question_content: I understand how to do inverses.. or so I thought..
How would I solve this problem...

4 + tan(pi x) , with -1/2 < x < 1/2

and why wouldn't the answer be 
y = arctan (x-4) / pi
what did  I do wrong?

If you solve this problem this way...
y=arcsin (x/8) + 12
x = arcsin (y/8) +12
sin(x-12) = y/8
y = 8sin(x-12) which gives me the correct answer.. how is the previous problem any different?


Thanks for the help! =) [SEP] best_answer: GIVEN : y= 4 + tan(pi x) , with -1/2 < x < 1/2

FINDING THE INVERSE FUNCTION:

y=4+ tan(pi*x) <=>
y-4=tan(pi*x) <=>
arctan(y-4)=pi*x <=>
arctan(y-4)/pi=x
now interchange x and y 
y=arctan(x-4)/pi
===========
I'm not able to see what you did wrong because you haven't showed us what you did, but I think you have made an error when you interchange x,y , Do always this at the end.

the example you have given at the end, I would solve this way:
y=arcsin (x/8) + 12<=>
sin(y-12)=x/8<=>
x=sin(y-12)*8
now interchange x and y
y=sin(x-12)*8

question_title: what are the mechanical properties of E8 steel? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: I  think you are talking about EN-8.
A plain carbon steel suitable for use where a good degree wear resistance combined with toughness is required but without the expense of an alloy steel.

Typical applications of EN8 include base plates for tools in plastic moulding and pressure casting dies, components for hand tools.


Since 1988 a new series of 'mandatory' European standards (EN = Europaischen Normen) has been created, to replace national standards, such as BS, DIN, SS and NF, throughout 18 countries of Western Europe. EN are a part of the 'Single Market' legislation, designed to give equal opportunities for firms to compete throughout Europe, by harmonising the technical requirements between countries. The national standards bodies, of which BSI is one, are required to officially withdraw their national standards, when an EN is created with the same scope of application.


A number of letters with there mechanical property identifiers are listed below
Letter Steel Use Mechanical Property... 
S Structural Steel Minimum Yield Strength 
P Pressure Purposes Minimum Yield Strength 
L Line Pipe Minimum Yield Strength 
E Engineering Minimum Yield Strength 
B Reinforcing Steel Characteristic Yield Case 
Y Pre-stressing Steel Minimum Yield Case 
R Rails Minimum Yield Case 
H High Strength Cold Rolled Minimum Yield Case 
D Flat Products for Cold Forming C, D or X followed by 
two numbers characterising steel 
T Tinmill Products Nominal Yield Case 
M Electrical Steel Number = 100 x specific loss in 
W/kg, "—" 
Number = 100 x nom thick in mm 
Letter for type of steel (A,B,E,N,S or P) 

EN 8 IS an old standard. AISI-1040 is the equivalent. The new standard would be BS 970 080M40.

question_title: if you work for long hours for a long period of time does your body adjust to this and act normal after awhile [SEP] question_content: My mom has been taking understandedibly tiring and long days of work for about a month and a half and she always gets home tired and ready to go to bed. I heard your body should adjust. But I wonder beacause i think she is just saying she is tired. I told her i didnt like her when she was on antidepressants and, she has taken them to get high before and I think she still is and just using the "tired act" just to get away with it, because she does act tired but also goofy too (the same as when she took the antidepressants). And im not sure if she is lying me or not. I want to confront her but i have tried before and she denied it so i just wanted to research a little.

sorry for the long story [SEP] best_answer: Unfortunately, the human body cannot adjust to sleep deprivation; it has only a limited capacity to absorb lack of rest, too.  It never totally adapts to either, frankly.

The fact that she has used antidepressants abusively is very much an issue to be worried about, however; on the whole, you have to work very hard to hurt yourself with the more modern antidepressants, but it's altogether possible to do so.  Much depends on the precise compound being used for her depression, but many of them will cause tiredness as a side effect.  You might get the name and do a quick search on the 'net on it.  (pdr.net might be available to you; worth a try if it is)

Offhand, I'd say there's a whole lot more going on here than you see--and perhaps more than the individual prescribing the antidepressants is aware of, too.  I realize that you feel your Mom is the one with the problem--you may well be right, too--but if I were in your shoes, I'd seek counseling.  You've got personal stresses generated by having to cope with this; those will take their toll on you, over time, if you don't get some assistance.  If you're still in pre-collegiate school, find a counselor to talk to; no matter what level of training you're in, maybe your clergy of choice would be a reasonable place to turn; or a professional counselor.

You can't solve your mom's problem; that's a guarantee.  She has to face it and solve it herself, though you can help her in that process.  All you can do is the best you can to keep her problems from damaging you.

Hope I've made sense...

question_title: (3x + 4)/6 = 2/5? [SEP] question_content: i was confused on this again [SEP] best_answer: Well, first you want to isolate the "x".  So, divide out the left side-this gets you 3x/6 + 4/6 = 2/5.  Take 4/6 from each side, so x/2 = 2/5 - 4/6.  You have to make the fractions have the same denominator, so you get x/2 = 12/30-20/30, or x/2 = -8/30.  Now multiply each side by 2, so you get x = -16/30, or x = -8/15.\nplug it back in to check, so (-24/15 + 60/15)/6 is the same as (36/15)/6, which is the same as 6/15, which reduces to 2/5.  O Ho! We got it!  x DOES equal -8/15..  That was fun-I havent done that kind of math for a long time..

question_title: how far??? [SEP] question_content: if your looking outside how far can  a person see in a distance? [SEP] best_answer: On a clear dark night you can see galaxies millions of lightyears away.  The horizon you see depends on how high above the ground you are.  One approximate formula for the distance in miles to the horizon is:
 distance =sqrt(1.5 x height)  
so if I'm 6 feet above the flat ground or better yet a flat ocean, my horizon is sqrt(9) = 3 miles.  This would work really well if the Earth were smooth like a bowling ball, but its rough and has mountains and valleys and hills and trees so the formula is idealized.  See wikipedia "horizon"
 In Modern industrialized countries, pollution often makes it difficult to see more than 20 miles unless you are way up in an airplane.

question_title: Does the University of South Carolina have any mountains or rivers located on or near it? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The University of South Carolina has several campuses, the main one being in Columbia where the School of Medicine is located. Columbia is in the lowlands and the Congaree River runs through the city about one mile from the  center of campus.

The nearest mountains of any size are the Great Smoky Mountains which are located at the border of North Carolina and Tennessee, about 200 miles (3 - 4 hours) North of Columbia. They are awesome and offer a lot of recreational activities but would make for a fairly long day trip from Columbia.

The USC Spartanburg campus is much closer to the mountains (1.5 - 2 hours) but is not near any rivers.

WK

question_title: Which part of the human brain releases dopamine & what are its effects? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Dopamine is not produced only in the brain. it is produced in a number of areas of the central and peripheral nervous systems -- chiefly in the hypothalamus, the arcuate nucleus, and the caudad.  
 
Dopamine plays a role in many different physiological processes, including skeletal movement to drug addiction. In addition dopamine's activities have been linked to cardiovascular, renal, hormonal, and central nervous systems.  
 
Both an excess of or deficiency of dopamine can cause disorders.  A deficiency in the striatum or substantia nigra results in Parkinson’s-like symptoms.  In this case, movement becomes slow and rigid, accompanied by muscle tremors. Drugs, such as L-DOPA, are used to alleviate these symptoms.  An excessive amount of dopamine is associated with schizophrenia.  Certain drugs, such as cocaine, block the return of dopamine into the brain, resulting in a build up of dopamine in the synapses, leading to drug-induced psychosis or schizophrenia.

question_title: wht is Fallen astronaut?? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Fallen Astronaut is an 8.5-cm aluminum sculpture of an astronaut in a spacesuit. It is the only piece of art on the Moon.

It was created by Belgian artist Paul Van Hoeydonck, who met astronaut David Scott at a dinner party. Van Hoeydonck was asked to create a small statuette to personally commemorate those astronauts and cosmonauts having lost their lives in the furtherance of space exploration. Van Hoeydonck was given a set of design restrictions: in addition to the physical requirements that the sculpture be both lightweight and sturdy, and that it be capable of withstanding the temperature extremes of the Moon, the statuette could not be identifiably male or female, nor of any identifiable ethnic group. Furthermore, in accordance with Scott's wish to avoid the commercialization of space, Van Hoeydonck's name would not be made public.

In 1971, Fallen Astronaut was placed on the Moon by the crew of Apollo 15, along with a plaque bearing the names of fourteen American astronauts and Russian cosmonauts who died during spaceflights or training exercises.

After the crew mentioned the statuette during their post-flight press conference, the National Air and Space Museum requested that a replica be made for public display. The crew agreed, under the condition that it was to be displayed "with good taste and without publicity"; in April of 1972, Van Hoeydonck presented the Museum with a replica of Fallen Astronaut, which is now on display with a replica of the plaque.

In May of 1972, Scott learned that Van Hoeydonck planned to make more replicas and sell them. Feeling that this would be a violation of the spirit of their agreement, Scott tried to persuade Van Hoeydonck to refrain, but was unsuccessful; 950 signed replicas went on sale for $750 apiece at the Waddell Gallery of New York.

Hope this helps.

question_title: What are 3 differences between quasars and pulsars? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: 1. Size -- quasars are huge structures, while pulsars are neutron stars about the size of Earth

2. Energy output -- quasars blast immense amounts of energy into space. Pulsars are more "quiet."

3. Rotation -- quasars seem to be relatively free of rapid motion, while pulsars spin at extremely high velocities (..about 1 revolution in less than a second.)

question_title: Is there end for universe? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The Universe is expanding, but it doesn't have a phyiscal start, middle, or an end.  It's going to expand forever. Don't think about it, because it's not something our mind can really grasp.

Here's an analogy that helped me:

Imagine the Universe as a two dimensional place.  The Universe is the surface of a rubber ball.  There's no start, finish, or middle.  As the Universe expands, the rubber ball fills with air.  Still no start, finish, or middle.

For a long time, it was unknown whether the Universe was open or closed, meaning whether the Universe would expand forever or eventually collapse back on itself back to nothing.

The hubble telescope proved that the Universe it open and would expand forever.

question_title: bursting bubbles? [SEP] question_content: Is it possible to burst a bubble underwater? [SEP] best_answer: Yes and a tremendous amount of energy is released by the bursting of the bubble (note this is BURSTING rather than simply dividing the bubble)

Objective evidence of this puzzled Victorian engineers for years- their hardended bronze propellers on ocean going liners would fail catastrophically with evidence of melting and severe attack...the root cause being the highly turbulent water created by the more effecient propeller design resulting in bursting bubbles and therby large amounts of energy.

It's not easy to do and a real problem in certain industrial environments- cavitation pumps used in moving ceramic slips/slurries display similar failures.

question_title: where is australia? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The Commonwealth of Australia is a country in the Southern Hemisphere comprising the world's smallest continent and a number of islands in the Southern, Indian and Pacific Oceans. Australia's neighbouring countries include Indonesia, East Timor and Papua New Guinea to the north, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and New Caledonia to the northeast, and New Zealand to the southeast.\n\nAustralia's 7,686,850 km² (2,967,909 mi²) landmass is on the Indo-Australian Plate. Surrounded by the Indian, Southern and Pacific oceans, Australia is separated from Asia by the Arafura and Timor seas.

question_title: how do i become a realtor in the usa? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Steps towards a successful real estate career 
Speak with Brokerages in the area where you would like to practice to find out about employment requirements and opportunities.

Complete the "Introduction to a Career in Real Estate" course provided at the Calgary Real Estate Board and pass the exam (refer to our Education Courses section). 

Enroll in the Alberta Real Estate Association’s Real Estate Agents Program provided at the Calgary Real Estate Board. (refer to our Education Courses section)

Qualify to write the licensing exam by attending a minimum of 90% of the classroom sessions.

Write and pass the qualifying exam.

Attend the CREB® Orientation to become a member of the Calgary Real Estate Board (refer to our Education Courses section). 

License - Register with a Real Estate Brokerage first, then obtain your license from the Real Estate Council of Alberta.

Practice your new career, and don’t forget to take your 18 hours of mandatory continuing education every two years to maintain your license.

To start the process of becoming a Realtor®, find out how you can register for the Real Estate Agents' Program in our Education Courses section

question_title: how many people are in labor force? [SEP] question_content: Given the following information, how many people are in the labor force? 3 million people are collecting unemployment insurance; 7 million  people are officially unemployed; 2 million people are discouraged workers; and 110 million people are employed. [SEP] best_answer: Discouraged workers don't count as being in the labor force.  The 7 million officially unemployed includes the 3 million collecting unemployment.  So your answer is 110 million employed + 7 million officially unemployed = 117 million in the labor force.

question_title: Learning english and need help with phrases!!? [SEP] question_content: Please help me with any of these questions！

They are talking about horse racing.
①man says:“So I was wondering if maybe you needed some horses looking after．Pretty anxious to train again”

this man has a brokendown horse and he talks to, once was, his owner(you). Does he means he is selling his horse and himself?

②I'm asking a job, I'd even be willing to...Cut my fee?
Does he mean it would be ok to have low payment if he get a job?

③Yeah, I think I'm gonna have to go with the second rule of horse racing.　Never beat a dead horse.

What is the second rule mean? [SEP] best_answer: 1. He appears to be asking the man if he needs someone to look after his horses. He is suggesting that he would like to do take this job as he is keen to get back into training horses which is what he has done before.

2. Yes. He is saying that he would be willing to accept less money than normal to do the job.

3. Beat a dead horse (actually the real expression is - Flog a dead horse) is an expression which means to do something which has no point because it is already settled. For example, if a child asked his mother for something and she said NO and would not change her mind, then to keep asking can be described as  - Beating (Flogging) a dead horse. In your example it possibly is referring to the pointlessness of asking for work when none is on offer. But it is also meant to be funny in this case because the subject is actually about horses :-)

The expression probably comes from the pointlessness of beating a horse (to make it work harder) if it is dead!!

question_title: why is aniline more reactive towards aromatic halogenation than acetanilide? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The free electrons in aniline are more available to "pump negative charge" into the aromatic system than acetanilide, where the positively charged carbon in the acetyle group draws the charge outward, lessening the activation effect.

question_title: economics questions...help!? [SEP] question_content: MS alicia tutors students. She charges $20 per hour when the quantity demanded per week is 30 hours, whereas she charges $25 when the quantity demanded per week is 28 hours.

1) To maximase her revenue, which price should she charge her students?

2) Ms alicia finds that she can raise her rate to $30 per hour during the week before final examination and students will continue to demand 28 hours of tutoring. Why is this so?

I'm having difficulties to do these questions. Thanks alot! [SEP] best_answer: a) My ans is the same as otbpoc

b) For the week before final examination, the demand for tution will increase. The demand curve for Alicia's service will shift upwards. Thus even if she increases the price per hour, the number of hours demanded could be the same.
(I used could because you dont know how much the demand curve will shift upwards)

Some definitions and explanations: 
Upward shift of the demand curve means that for the same number of hours(qty), the price will be higher.

question_title: henry hudson's fourth voyage? [SEP] question_content: Wat did he do on his fourth voyage help me plz. [SEP] best_answer: Henry Hudson's Fourth Voyage
1610: The Northwest Passage

More info at link below:

    Henry Hudson managed to get support from English backers for another voyage, this time in search of a Northwest Passage, one he had wanted to pursue almost since the start of his voyages. The main sponsor this time was Sir Thomas Smythe - governor and treasurer of the Virginia Company, and also of the English East India Company. Smythe desperately needed to recoup his losses after a disaster that saw his last fleet to Virginia scattered, with hundreds of men lost. He may not have paid Hudson for his services - rather, it may have been Hudson's payment for Smythe getting Hudson out of house arrest. 

The voyage started inauspiciously with a company man put off the ship and a another man brought aboard - Henry Greene, a gambler who would prove a partner in trouble with Juet. Almost from the start there was trouble with the crew. Hudson's ability to manage his crew appears even weaker than in previous voyages. There were fights and almost a mutiny within the first few months, before they even reached the area Hudson intended to explore.

Discovery ended up sailing through the treacherous Arctic waters north of modern Quebec - the Furious Overfall - known today as Hudson's Strait although he did not discover it - and into a large body of water now known as Hudson Bay.

By the fall of the year the crew was stuck hundreds of miles south, unable to go further or to get home. They had to endure a harsh winter in that hostile land, during which one crewman died and most others were sickened by scurvy or lack of food. Again, Hudson's showed his inability to deal with the natives and his own crew during the cold months they spent ashore.

By late next spring, the ship was ready to sail again. Hudson wanted to continue his explorations, but the crew only wanted to head home. Fights broke out over food and Hudson accused some crew members of hoarding. They in turn accused him of the same. Eventually a large number of crew members, led by Juet and Greene, decided to mutiny. They put the captain, his son and others they didn't like into a small shallop and set it adrift while the Discovery sailed away. None of the abandoned crew were ever seen again.

question_title: what range of TOEFL Score is considered very good? [SEP] question_content: what range of TOEFL Score is considered very good in case of CBT where total score is 300. If u want to get admission in TOP scholls what is the requirement of TOEFL score [SEP] best_answer: TOEFL Score Interpretation

D.W. McKeon, Director, ESL & GTA Training Programs 

Executive Summary 
I. Introduction
II. Overall Scores and Subscores 
III. Other Factors Affecting TOEFL Scores 
IV. The Old GRE Verbal Section and the TOEFL 
V. The New GRE Analytical Writing Section and the TOEFL 


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Executive Summary

The Test of English as a Foreign Language, TOEFL, developed in the early 1960’s, has become the main instrument of measuring English language proficiency for international students around the world. A total score (range of 310-677) was determined based on the scores of three subsections: Listening, Structure, and Reading; (note: an optional essay was administered at every other international testing date, the Test of Written English, TWE, with a score range of 0 to 6). 

In the late 1990’s, the TOEFL Board produced a computer-based test (CBT; range: 40 to 300. Other than the supposed ease of electronic test-taking, the CBT TOEFL made a few notable improvements on the paper-based test (PBT); to mention two: (1) it includes linear testing (from easy to difficult) and computer-adaptive testing (tailoring to the proficiency level of the individual test-taker); and (2) it includes a compulsory essay, whose score is factored into the Structure section and is reported in a separate Essay Section, equivalent to the former TWE. A Concordance Table was published in 1998, providing equivalences between the familiar PBT scores and the new CBT ones. Since the CBT is not administered at every site where the PBT was, the PBT continues to be used in various parts of the world. 

Graduate School admissions committees have generally used a 550 (=213 CBT) cutoff score, but often without consideration of the total profile of subscores. In light of their near magical aura to the aggregate TOEFL scores, below are some recommendations on the use of TOEFL (either form) for admissions committees:

Regardless of the total score, subscores must be taken into consideration 
Listening subscores should not be below 50/16, regardless of the total, aggregate score 
Essay Writing subscores should not be below 4.0 (same rating as TWE scores) 
Since neither PBT nor CBT TOEFL versions measure one’s speaking ability, admissions committees considering offering teaching assistants with teaching duties should not use TOEFL scores alone in such decisions (certainly Listening scores should be a factor) 
The number of times (and length of intervals) a prospective student has taken the TOEFL should be considered as a factor (read, test-wiseness as an issue) 
Date of last administration and activity in using English since then should be factored in the decision to accept an applicant or not 
Finally, TOEFL scores have never meant to be predictors of academic success. 
Return to top 
I. Introduction

Having been developed in the mid 1960’s, the TOEFL has become the major standard of measuring proficiency in English as a second language throughout the world . Because of its widespread use in determining admissions into colleges and universities, TOEFL scores have taken on a sort of magical aura to them. One rather unfortunate consequence is the emergence of innumerable TOEFL preparation courses—not to mention TOEFL preparation centers—throughout the world: the tail is indeed wagging the dog. Even more unfortunate is the temptation to view one’s TOEFL scores as an indicator of general intelligence or as a predictor of academic success, despite the TOEFL Board’s insistence to the contrary. 

Although the TOEFL Board introduced a computer-based version in 1997 to replace paper-based testing, the latter is still prevalent in many parts of the world. Thus, in general, TOEFL scores in the 310-677 range (paper-based test) are still more familiar than those in the 40-300 range (computer-based test).

Like the paper-based test (PBT), the c

question_title: understanding imagery in poetry? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Using imagery is appealing to 1 (or more) of the 5 senses.  For example:  If I give you the sentence "John is strong", you have an image in your head.  If however, I say "John is as strong as an ox" you have a much more vivid image in your mind because of the comparison that is made.  This is an example of visual imagery but often authors try to appeal to other senses for more effective writing.

question_title: what nutrient foods do i need to eat to get taller? [SEP] question_content: I'm 16 years old, and stopped getting tall, what kind of foods do i need to eat to able to grow taller? But now Im 21 and I grew to 5'5 1/2. I had another growth spurt at around age 20 and grew three inches in one year. Especially after I started eating calcum chews.

I think the key is to take advantage of your growth spurts. Eat more vitamins and calcium supplements. Also since I sleept on a firmer bed I lengthened my back. After a few years of sleeping like this I think It helped out alot.

question_title: Is anybody studying or has studied TEFL? [SEP] question_content: Any advice? Worth it? If you are now teaching, where are you working and how good is the money? Thanks! [SEP] best_answer: The TEFL is an excellent course. It will take you anywhere you want to go. You can do the course online or at your local college or learning centre. There are also variations of the course available. However, depending on where you are going you may not need one (although it's good to have a backup) For example if you go to Thailand or Bangkok you can easily pick up work teaching English. A friend of mine found work in a day and carried on to be very successful there. In places like Thailand when teaching English the student you teach are paying for the privilege and must try to speak only English while in your class.
The money you'll be paid there is good when compared to the national average and is enough to give you a descent standard of living. Over there you can live well on about £350 a month. You'll find accommodation and costs of living to be less than western countries. If you're thinking of travelling and working abroad you should try getting in contact with different charities that do projects in these countries and ask them about it. They'll be able to give allot of good information relating to the place you have in mind. They'll be able to give you a more accurate estimate of how much it will cost you and such.

Good Luck honey, if you go, have a blast... You'll love it!

question_title: Are there any websites or chat rooms for parents of kids with ADHD/ODD who live in Downriver Mich? [SEP] question_content: We're in the Riverview school district. I just went to one of the worst I.E.P.'s we've had yet.  These schools just want you to increase your kids meds. What's the point of them deeming your child Emotionally Impaired if they still expect him to act and function like all the rest and act shocked when he doesn't.  Now they want to send him to summer school and I can't provide the transport cuz I have to work!  Anyone have any suggestions? I'd really like to hear some feedback in regards to the summer school (or lack of going). thanks, DBMOM [SEP] best_answer: Here are some places to start:

http://www.chaddmi.com/
http://www.bridges4kids.org/PAC.html (scroll down to list of parent advocacy groups)
http://www.bridges4kids.org/HelpForKids.html
http://www.conductdisorders.com/
http://www.wrightslaw.com/
http://www.causeonline.org/


For someone who is ED, learning proper behavior is difficult. For the "normal" person, behavior reflects feelings, and is appropriate for the social context. However, B/ED people have feelings that do not match their environment, and/or their natural behavioral responses are not socially acceptable.  Therefore, their big challenge in learning is to build "unnatural" behavior patterns to meet society's expectations. The world will not change to fit them...they must change to fit the world. Life is not fair...and never has been.

The purpose of special education is to help children who are different, learn to function effectively in the mainstream society. If your child does not learn to control his own behavior by the time he is an adult, he WILL end up in prison (the prison population is full of people with ADHD, ED, etc.). 

Your son is not in special education to be coddled, "allowed to be himself," or enabled in his use of maladaptive behaviors. He is in special education so that he can be guided toward appropriate behaviors.

The question you should be raising is not "why are they appearing to attack my son?" but rather "Are they providing appropriate instruction in behavior skills so that HE can learn to control himself?" AND "Am I being trained, as a parent, in these techniques so that I can use them at home and provide him with stability across all environments?"  AND "What am I already doing at home to bring about changes in his behavior so that my baby boy won't spend a life behind bars?"

question_title: What are the pros and cons of school vouchers? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Pros:
Allows lower income people to send their kids to private school.
Allows parents to choose where they send their kids to school
Rewards good schools, punishes bad schools

Cons:
Takes money out of an already cash-strapped public school system
Public schools are not allowed to turn down students, so students who aren't accepted by private schools will be stuck in even worse public schools.

question_title: could you please elaborate to me the relationship between research and pedagogy? [SEP] question_content: how can pedagogy be a theory? [SEP] best_answer: I like to think of pedagogy as the art of teaching a particular subject.  The way to explain topics so that they are best understood in an effiecient way.  
With that said, a theory is an idea that has not been proved or disproved.  I think that because we have not perfected the way people learn best, that within pedagogy there can be theories about how people learn.

Research usually has more to do with collecting information.  When we do research for papers, we gather information to prove our point from a variety of sources.  Scientific research gathers information through experiments to support a hypothesis.

question_title: Where is the best Paramedic School in the US? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: There really isn't a "best" school.\nEvery area has basically the same content that has to be taught in the class.  Every class is going to focus a bit more on the things you'll see in that area.  Case in point... Indiana school isn't going to teach a GREAT deal on poisonous snake bits because they don't have many poisonous snakes.  Go near the ocean and they will focus strongly on drownings.  The criteria for the classes are set at a national level and therefore, the basics of the classes will all be the same.

question_title: I've just been diagnosed dyslexic, and find it hard to motivate myself to start assignments. Any advice? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Wow, your doctor is full of shit. Just, wow.

Dyslexia doesn't make sense for the inability to focus. A simple test: bdqp. What does that say? If you can read that and know which sequence it is, you aren't even dyslexic in the right way to effect reading at all. You could have a problem called ADD, or you could have a combination of the two like I did. ADD means you can't focus and get easily distracted, among other things:

Scan these:
http://www.webmd.com/diseases_and_conditions/add_adhd.htm
http://borntoexplore.org/whatisadd.htm

There is no easy way to deal with ADD, other than learning to cope. For the dyslexia, I just had to grow out of it (but still confuse right and left once in a while) I still don't study well unless I retreat to someplace quiet where there are practically no distractions, like a library. Ritalin is one solution, but you may or may not like its effects. My brother took the stuff and it didn't do a damn thing, but it helps some people.

The only plus side is that you will probably make a good scientist or engineer or artist anything where you need visualization skills. I can't do abstract math, but with a physics problem where there is something to visualize I am faster than blue blazes. I also do photography well enough to get recognized as art, although I lack the coordination or patience for drawing by hand. I can also think in five dimensions, but I haven't found a use. Perhaps you will be an architect or a sculptor? Thomas Edison was probably ADD too.

Remember the trick about going to a library or something to study!

question_title: Does it affect your performance in the exam whether you have breakfast in the morning or not? If you got a splinter on that morning, your focus sure would be distrated from the exam.  If one of your friends ignored you that morning, it sure would affect your thinking.  So something as simple as having a routine breakfast does make a difference.

The very best a person can do just prior to an exam is to keep everything as calm and normal as reasonable.  Don't press or cram in any way.  Simple get up the usual time, do routine morning things, get out the door and stay happy and positive.

That is the secret to positive performance

question_title: who is Captain Hook? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Captain Hook
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

 
Captain Hook as seen in the Disney version of Peter Pan.Captain James Hook is the (so-called) villain of J. M. Barrie's play and novel Peter Pan. Hook is a pirate captain and Peter Pan's nemesis. It is said that he was Blackbeard's bosun, and that he was the only man Long John Silver ever feared. He wears an iron hook in place of his left hand, which was cut off by Peter Pan and eaten by a crocodile; the crocodile liked the taste of him so much that it follows him around constantly, hoping for more. Hook hates Peter obsessively, and lives for the day he can make Peter and all his Lost Boys walk the plank.

Lest anyone think Hook's name too convenient, Barrie notes that "Hook was not his true name. To reveal who he really was would even at this date set the country in a blaze." Barrie also suggests through several clues that the Captain was an Old Etonian - in Barrie’s short story “Jas Hook at Eton,” Hook’s final words before jumping overboard are “Floreat Etona” (115).

In Barrie's play and novel, Hook kidnaps Wendy, the girl who loves Peter and whom Peter views as his surrogate mother, and challenges the boy to a final duel. When Hook is bested and must choose between surrender and death, he commits suicide by throwing himself into the waiting jaws of the crocodile. Just before dying, however, he takes a final jab at Peter by taunting him about his "bad form". Peter, with the callousness of youth, quickly forgets Hook and finds a new nemesis, but as Hook made a stronger impression on the public, most sequels brought him back one way or another.

The symbolism of Peter Pan's fight with Captain Hook (traditionally played by the same actor as Wendy's father), combined with Hook's fear of time in the form of the ticking crocodile, possibly hints at Jungian subtext.

It is hypothesized that Captain Hook was modeled after the famous English captain Christopher Newport. Both were dark-haired captains of dubious pasts, and both were missing their right hands which were replaced by metal hooks. Newport commanded the ships that landed the settlers at Jamestown in Virginia. He also seems to have a distinctive similarity to Bartholomew Roberts, especially regarding his choice of clothes and his impeccable manners, although Barrie specifically associates his dress and hairstyle with that of King Charles II of England.

Another hypothesis claims that Captain James Hook could represent Captain James Cook, the British captain who discovered both Australia and New Zealand. The Lost Boys symbolize the Maoris, who inhabit New Zealand, or the Aborigines, who inhabit Australia.

Smee is Captain Hook's bosun and right-hand man, so to speak.

question_title: Why do teachers ignore certain students? [SEP] question_content: This doesnt happen to me often, but it happened a lot in this one certain class.  I had an A+ in the class because I did the homework and took tests well, but the teacher still treated me terribly campared to the other kids.  They were allowed to start open discussions without having to raise hands and whatever.  So I thought that was cool.  But when ever I made a comment she refused to respond or 'shushed' me; which I found extremely degrading.  Also I found her to be very fake and a lot of what she told us about the world was wrong.  Her facts were totally wrong and these were like common knowledge to me.  So I would say my comment to say that she was wrong, but believe me I did this respectfully.  But she gave me a dirty look and continued with her 'mind-tainting' lecture.  It was absurd.  Why would she do that? Does she just not know better? (oh yea she isnt a new teacher, apparently she's been doing this like forever) [SEP] best_answer: My son's first experience in school in Kindergarten got him one of those teachers.  We butted heads all the time.  She labeled him a trouble maker because he didn't stay on task and wanted to move faster than the class did.  I told her that she was wrong so I was the demanding parent.

Teachers come in all types and some are just not good or have worn out their welcome.  Some fear change.  Some are threatened easily and when there is a smart student they feel it and react badly.

If there is an issue that she is wrong about (or any teacher in the future too) bring in proof that you are right in writing.  I did and, yes it made my teacher MAD, but the other students then started to question her and she was forced to prove herself the rest of the way through.  You may not be the favorite in class with that teacher but you will be respected by your fellow students.  If the teacher threatens to fail you for speaking up (like mine did) go higher up (principal, dean, etc) with the proof.

You're an A+ student.  Let her know it!

question_title: Is an SAT score of 1770 okay? [SEP] question_content: Or should I retake it? [SEP] best_answer: It sounds like the new scoring systems has everyone a bit confused... some schools asked for all three scores, but only consider the reading & math scores.

Here are average scores on the most recent test: 520 math and 508 verbal for a combined score of 1028.  The most selective schools (e.g., ivy league) typically had SAT averages north of 1400 (combined math & verbal, not all three tests).

So I guess it's a question of how you did on the math & verbal, and what is your goal in terms of schools.  You can find out what your target schools' average SAT scores for entering Freshmen by looking on their websites or contacting their admissions offices.

question_title: in act 5 scene 1 of hamlet can u describe the attitude towards corruption expressed by Horatio? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Horatio doesn't say much in act 5, scene 1. Consider that he's Hamlet's foil throughout the play, then look at Horatio's response to Hamlet's comments about the lawyers and politicians who used to be those skulls. He responds very gently to Hamlet's tirades, and seems like he's there to say, "yes, corruption is bad, but it's within some people, and they are now skulls, so they got what's coming to them" and wants to assure Hamlet to despise corruption, but tolerate it and be true to himself.\n\nLook at Horatio's first line in the scene, "Custom hath made it in him a property of easiness". It seems his function in that scene is to let Hamlet know that people are made by their social status

question_title: plz help me i am in desperate need of advice? [SEP] question_content: so junior prom is coming up right, and there's boy that i liked. my cousin had asked him if he wanted to take me to prom he said yes and we both agreed that we would go as friends. then the same night that my cousin asked him, we were hanging out in our development, and all of a sudden he just kisses me, tounge and everything, then he tells me that even though i did that, i am not looking for a relationship, i said neither am i. so two days after this happened, he haventh said a word to me and he seem to be ignoring me. what do you think happened? and to add he is white and i am black and we live in pennsylvania [SEP] best_answer: Two possibilities: 
- he wants to have the benefits but not the responsibility. Perhaps he was just letting you know how he'd like your friendship to be. You know, fooling around but not committing.
- in reality, he wants to have a relationship with you, but is afraid to ask or is afraid that you would not be down with it. So by saying he doesn't want to committ, he was testing the waters to see how you thought about this. 

My personal guess is that the first option is more like it. He's a guy, and guys like to think of themselves as players. Unless you have no problem with being casual friends with benefits, then no prob. But if it disturbs you that he wants the goods but not you, then you're better off with someone who wants the whole package.

In any case, make sure he still wants to go to prom with you. He sounds a bit like a jerk (sorry, but he's ignoring you!). Make sure that YOU have a date!

question_title: My girlfriend Dad ask my Goals and priority's..short and long term.What you feel you must do to act? [SEP] question_content: My grilfriend Dad ask my goals and my prioritys in an email and I just need second opinions just to be more confident with my answer.

"Goals and priority's..short and long term...What you feel you must do to accompolish them, and your plans for making them a reality"??? Any help please??? [SEP] best_answer: Whether or not you decide to tell him, he did you a favor by asking you this question. Every person should ask themselves this. You should keep asking yourself this, as often as it takes, until you are completely confident in the answer for yourself. This is what it takes to take control of your life, to make yourself into the person you want to be. 

Don't be afraid to have high expectations, as long as your resolve and commitment to your dreams are strong. Somebody really wise once said, "It is only by attempting the absurd that you cam achieve the impossible."

Back to your girlfriend and her Dad. Best to say you are giving it serious thought and will get back to them.

[SEP] best_answer: If you're miserable in your marriage and you have tried unsuccessfully to work things out with your husband then there is only one thing you can do--SHOW HIM THE DOOR.  Trust me...I was in a dead-end marriage and was totally miserable.  The only reason I stayed in the marriage as long as I did was for the kids. But now I look back at it and realize that I should have left him long before we even got married, because there were signs there that things weren't going to be right.

So many times us women think if we just stick things out things will change, or even we can change the man.  But sadly that doesn't happen, and for you to stay in a marriage
where you feel alone is only going to hurt you.  Life is short--you deserve to be happy and feel loved and like you have a partner in your relationship.

Regarding your previous split with your husband, it sounds like he was almost over-doing it in fear of losing you.  It shouldn't take the fear of losing you to make him treat you like his wife.  Cut him loose, and when he comes a wooing tell him "Sorry, you had your chance."  Then get out there and find you a good man.  You'll be glad you did.

question_title: I'm single parent never been married Traveling to kuwit need proff of custudy.What do  need? [SEP] question_content: I'M SINGLE PARENT NEVER BEEN MARRIED AND I'M TAKING MY CHILD TO  KUWAIT & THEY ARE ASKING FOR PROOF OF CUSTUDY, WHAT DO I NEED AND WHERE TO I GO FOR IT? ALOS I NEED A DOCMENT TO SAY IV'E NEVER BEEN MARRIED ? WHAT DO I NEED & WHERE DO I GET IT FROM? PLEASE ANY ONE  TELL ME. THANX FOR READING THIS [SEP] best_answer: Are you in the military?  If so your dependent would be listed on your orders.

If not, a birth certficate should list you as the parent.  If the father was also on the birth certificate you may have more of a problem.  If you have not been to court to establish custody, they may view you as kidnapping your child.  

Would need more detail to say for sure but if the father is on the Birth Certificate you may have to file court documents for custody or maybe a notarized letter may work???  Check with the US Embassy in Kuwait.

As for a document saying you've never been married, not sure there is such a thing.  Just because you have not been married in one state does not mean you weren't marrried in another.  You would need proof from all 50 states saying you haven't been married???

question_title: What should I do about my 'mother'? [SEP] question_content: My adoptive mother has always had a problem with me. She abused me as a child, and even though I tried to forgive her for it over the years, she has continuously hurt me. She feels that I cannot be happy. She has tried to make me leave the man of my dreams, and when I sent her some ultrasound pictures of our son, she refused everything at the post office. Neither of us have spoken to her since, but what should I do? Should I leave things alone knowing that I'd probably be better off without her, or should I take yet another step to trying to include her in my life? [SEP] best_answer: How sad for you. You need to ask yourself if you and your unborn children are better off without her. If she doesn't show you any love or compassion, then she certainly won't show your children any, which will only hurt you more in the long run. Have you tried calling her and asking her why she would miss the opportunity to be in her grandchildrens lives? If she still refuses to talk to you, chalk it up to God's work and move on without her. What does your Dad have to say about all this? Maybe he could be your "rock" when it comes to dealing with Mom.\nGood Luck and remember you still have your Mother in Law to lean on and show you some support......I know because your story is the same as my daughter in laws and I love her as if she was my own.

question_title: Is it possible to think that you are divorced and then find out you really aren't? [SEP] question_content: My boyfriend said he was divorced.  Years ago, he had gone to a paralegal and had most of the divorce paper work completed. (I have seen the papers and his child custody agreement.) I found out he was still legally married.  He told me that he looked into it and that he really wasn't divorced because the paralegal didn't file the papers with the judge.  Is this possible?  Is a person stupid to not know if they are divorced or not?  Am I stupid for even wondering? [SEP] best_answer: It's possible, but unlikely.  He is not divorced til those papers are signed, sealed and delivered.  He's been lazy in finding out.  If he has no paperwork, he doesn't care whether he's divorced or not.  Or, he's just lazy.  If he's truly serious about you, he should make sure his divorce is final.  If you have to drive him to the courthouse yourself.
I was not in a hurry to get the paperwork done, until I knew I was ready to remarry.  Well, that time came and I went to the nearest paralegal and had them get it done in time.  To make sure, I filed them myself.

I hope everything works out for you.
